text:
After the Earth first formed, the temperatures were higher than they are now. Anaerobic life evolved and flourished in conditions with high methane and CO2 levels for hundreds of millions of years. Then Cyanobacteria came into being and consumed the CO2 while releasing oxygen, creating a great dying off of the anaerobics.  The CO2 levels got so low that the Earth became what scientists call Snowball Earth. Eventually, however, the CO2 and oxygen levels balanced out and new life forms evolved and flourished in the pre-Cambrian Period. After this, the great extinctions that occurred were when CO2 or SO2 levels soared due to extended periods of basaltic flows such as those that created the Siberian Traps (associated with the Great Dying) and the Deccan traps (that drove the dinosaurs towards extinction before the Chicxulub asteroid strike).
Mega Eruptions, Large Igneous Provinces and Extinctions:
https://samslair.blogspot.com/2019/07/mega-eruptions-disrupt-climate-and.html?m=1

text:
Is this the hottest period on record? Thermometer and satelite readings only go back a few decades, not a basis for establishing long term trends or anomalies. The geological record demonstrates that the global temperature was at least double that of today's, and life was thriving. In fact, we live in an interglacial ice age:¬† the Holocene. The current interglacial period is older than other similar periods. If there is a trend we are due for more cooling.
20th century rates of warming:
1910-1940¬†- 0.5¬∞ per 30 yrs
1940 to 1980 there was cooling
1980-2000¬†- 0.4¬∞ per 30 yrs (lower rate)
Previous rates were much higher:
1326 bc global warming rate: 1.4¬∞ per century
6440 bc global warming rate: 1.9¬∞ per century
9620 bc global warming rate 100¬∞ per century. This is the start of the Holocene interglacial. The rate was more than 111x that of late 20th century rate.
1817 bc 50¬∞ per century

Medieval Warm Period¬†
1100's to 1300's¬†
The MGWP was 0.25¬∞ warmer than today
Vikings grew crops in Greenland and had settlements on the coast of northern of Canada.

text: No decision whatsoever should be made by any Government, company or individual that is based purely on the false science that claims one molecule of CO2 in every 2,500 other air molecules could warm Earth's surface.  In fact the main greenhouse gas water vapor cools the surface by several degrees as correct physics explains and studies of real world data confirm.  That single fact refutes the IPCC claim that water vapor does most of "33 degrees" of warming. Increasing water vapor does not increase the temperature gradient by raising the surface temperature: instead it reduces the gradient as is well known by meteorologists. Carbon dioxide is not a pollutant and is of significant benefit in agriculture for a starving world. Real pollution could be handled in other ways with existing technology, and the hundreds of billions spent on useless carbon dioxide studies could be allocated to pollution reduction, starting with many Asian countries.  It could also build and operate quite a few hospitals in developing countries. See https://itsnotco2.wordpress.com

text:
None of these are examples of Evolution.

Evolution would be natural selection of random point mutations (GATC.) It hasn't been shown that mutations occurred and were the source of the described variations. This ignores that there is a certain amount of variation in all reproduction of offspring. Thank goodness or everyone would look the same. Variety is both nice and useful. If you have 3 children and they are slightly different in height, hair color, health and temperament does this mean specific point mutations occurred within that one generation to cause these variations? No, this is simply genetic variety within a kind. Everyone has tens of thousands of genes which when combined with the opposite sex produces a new unique set of genes. Some are expressed to varying degrees leading to variation in size, color, etc. Mendelian breeding or natural selection based on outside pressures can cause some gene combinations to predominate. No mutations required!

As to the examples in the video, here is a crude example. If some cruel dictator killed all the blond, red or brown haired people and only the black haired people remained and in future generations black haired people predominated did evolution occur? No! So too in all the examples above. If some pressure simply eliminated other already existing varieties so one predominates, that is not evolution. Similar if some descendants in the normal range of variation within a kind are naturally thicker shelled, faster or have a better immune system they may eventually predominate.

If you were designing something to exist on it's own, would you make it very rigid to particular conditions so that as soon as environment changed it would be wiped out, or would you wisely build in a certain amount of variation so that at least some of them could survive and reproduce no matter what? Why be surprised our Creator would build a certain amount of useful variation into his creation?

Realize differences are mainly superficial. Among humans gene combinations from reproduction may result in a wonderful variety in size, color, hair, shape, etc but other necessary internal things such as how our blood, lungs, nerves, digestion, reproduction, cells, etc work quite similar for everyone, thank goodness. Our eyes might be different colors, but they work the same.

Thank you for your time, If you are open minded to examining evidence on both sides of this important issue read and consider the following:

text: +Viktor Ostapenko yes, they will produce something very similar to, but not genetically the same as a dog. You will never be able to pinpoint the exact generation where it happens though. I like to use aging as an example. What is the exact point when a boy becomes a man? We all know this doesn't magically happen on his 18th birthday, it is a gradual process. Yet if you look at pictures of the boy several years apart, there is a clear difference. In this way, aging is very similar to evolution, in the sense that you cannot pinpoint events in the way some would like. It is so gradual that it goes by unnoticed as it is happening and can only be identified when looked at with large enough time spans in between.
author: Onoku

text: ¬†@ProYagu¬†¬†In biology a clade is defined as every organisms having evolved from a given species (including that species). So like I said, if we treat dogs as a clade then dogs will indeed only produce dogs, but they may become something very different from what we see today and we could get more than one species of dogs.

text: ¬†@Viktor Ostapenko¬†¬†They don't evolve into something other than a dog. They evolve into different dogs. And if enough generations pass with a high selection pressure, they may evolve into dogs so different you wouldn't recognize them as dogs at first glance.

text: ¬†@Kamizushi Akinari¬†¬†Putting dogs into a clade doesn't change anything. All you are doing is showing that all of the creatures in that clade came from a common ancestor. The new species that are no longer dogs can also be put into their own clade nested within the dog clade. That nesting of clades can be done to encompass the entire tree. It does not change that eventually the species in the nested clade is no longer a dog.¬†

author: Onoku

text: Chance and randomness do factor into evolution and the history of life in many different ways; however, some important mechanisms of evolution are non-random and these make the overall process non-random. For example, consider the process of natural selection, which results in adaptations ‚Äî features of organisms that appear to suit the environment in which the organisms live (e.g., the fit between a flower and its pollinator, the coordinated response of the immune system to pathogens, and the ability of bats to echolocate). Such amazing adaptations clearly did not come about "by chance." They evolved via a combination of random and non-random processes. The process of mutation, which generates genetic variation, is random, but selection is non-random. Selection favored variants that were better able to survive and reproduce (e.g., to be pollinated, to fend off pathogens, or to navigate in the dark). Over many generations of random mutation and non-random selection, complex adaptations evolved. To say that evolution happens "by chance" ignores half of the picture.
author: Onoku

text:
¬†@ProYagu¬†¬†But ignoring evolution is based on chance is ignoring the very foundation of evolution without which it doesn't exist. You mentioned¬†Symbiosis which is a big problem for evolution and is not explained by it at all. To have two or more life forms have genetic mutations that lead to a co-dependence is miraculous for once, improbable for twice and simply impossible for the thousands we see. Natural selection only can occur after a genetic defect becomes beneficial and not destructive to the creature and survives DNAs error correction and is then able to be passed on to offspring.¬†

An awful lot of random chances, don't you think?
author: wmpratt2010

text: Symbiosis doesn't require genetic mutations in both parties. In the case of a flower, it is selected based being most attractive and accessible to the pollinator. The pollinator doesn't necessarily need any mutations. or in the opposite case, the pollinator, such as a hummingbird, is the one with the mutation. It isn't quite as random as you make it out to be.
author: Onoku

text: ¬†@ProYagu¬†¬†At the end of the day, out of the 4000+ genetic mutations in human DNA not one of them is even remotely considered beneficial. We just don't see in nature what evolution claim exists.¬†Spina bifida that rarely allows people with it to grow into adulthood and never allows them to reproduce if they do, whats that doing in the gene pool?¬†
author: wmpratt2010

text: +wmpratt2010 One important mechanism of evolution, natural selection, does result in the evolution of improved abilities to survive and reproduce; however, this does not mean that evolution is progressive ‚Äî for several reasons. First, natural selection does not produce organisms perfectly suited to their environments. It often allows the survival of individuals with a range of traits ‚Äî individuals that are "good enough" to survive. Hence, evolutionary change is not always necessary for species to persist. Many taxa (like some mosses, fungi, sharks, opossums, and crayfish) have changed little physically over great expanses of time.
author: Onoku

text: +wmpratt2010 Second, there are other mechanisms of evolution that don't cause adaptive change. Mutation, migration, and genetic drift may cause populations to evolve in ways that are actually harmful overall or make them less suitable for their environments. For example, the Afrikaner population of South Africa has an unusually high frequency of the gene responsible for Huntington's disease because the gene version drifted to high frequency as the population grew from a small starting population.
author: Onoku

text: +wmpratt2010 Lastly, you are mischaracterizing Spina Bifida. The causes of it are not well understood and likely are a combination of both genetic and environmental factors. Many patients with Spina Bifida are able to reproduce. A quick search on your part would have cleared that up.
author: Onoku

text: ¬†@ProYagu¬†¬†In the absence of modern medical intervention, many genetic disorders would not be passed on.They should not exist today but they do.¬†
author: wmpratt2010

text:
+Lorie Franceschi Then again, why should we contribute to species more rapidly go extinct.  Even though you're right about different species going extinct, but keep in mind that the "background rate" is 5 to 1 species per year.  Alarming reports have shown that right now the rate that species are going extinct is that of 1000 to 10000 time the background rate. 

http://www.biologicaldiversity.org/programs/biodiversity/elements_of_biodiversity/extinction_crisis/ 

What you seem to fail to understand is also that our existence is heavily reliant on a strong and healthy biological diversity. When we're discussing the relation between humans and the ecosystem, we're using the therms "technosphere" and "biosphere"; Technosphere being human society and Biosphere being the existing ecosystem. The biosphere provides services like cultural, resources through exploitation and filtering human waste products emitted by different types of industry. If the biological diversity is reduced, so is the services that we get from our biosphere.

text: This video didn't give any examples that creationists disagree with. So there are two genetic options for a species, and one variant survives better than the other ‚Äî creationists don't have a problem with that. What creationists argue is that natural selection cannot create new genetic information that did not previously exist within that group of animals (which is not the the same thing as a specific species, either). All it can do is select information that was already there. Mutations may create new information, but are most often harmful and occasionally benign ‚Äî almost never helpful. Mutation really can't logically  account for the genetic diversity in the world today.

text: +Bill Smith I would first off note that wildlife adapted to five previous 'great extinctions', or there would be no wildlife around for this one. That said, this current one will not likely turn out to be a great extinction simply because it is going to be very short lived relatively speaking. The problems that are resulting in it are very short lived and will likely be past us within just a few decades. For instance the only reason we are not using fully renewable energy sources right now is because they are more expensive than fossil fuels. Give it a couple more decades as the technologies for alternate energy matures, getting both better and cheaper, while increasing demand and dwindling supply of fossil fuels increases the cost of those, and within a very short time span, no one in their right mind will be burning expensive fossil fuels when they could be using much cheaper solar and such.
